Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Tandem-ABALONE Detector Module
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is many-fold. The novel photosensor technology developed within this project will enable a new generation of ultrasensitive experiments in the broad field of astroparticle physics?designed and constructed on previously impossible scales This technology is advantageous as detectors of ultrahigh energy cosmic radiation, neutrinos, dark matter and more. In addition, our technology addresses societal needs, including advancements in medical imaging and nuclear security. In medical application, the same core technology can enable the production of cost-effective ultrasensitive whole-body-enclosing medical scanners (patent pending) for preventive, virtually harmless (low-dose) cancer screening of the symptom-free population (a currently non-existent service). For nuclear security application, this technology can enable widespread and cost-effective detection of illicit fissionable and radioactive materials (also a currently non-existent possibility). In general, this project can lead to the creation of a highly profitable and multi-faceted hi-tech industry.

The proposed project will meet the needs of our lead customer/partner, an international collaboration aiming at the detection of cosmic neutrino radiation at the South Pole site with unprecedentedly high sensitivity. Such sensitivity will be achieved in a volume of 10km^3 of ice, instrumented with 2500 m deep chains of detectors, and only a detector concept and cost-effective hi-tech production method like ours can reach that goal. However, harsh conditions at the experimental site require specific modifications to the core design of our invention. Pairs of modified photosensors will need to be packed into each detector unit, which will be electrically grounded on its surface, so the standard high-voltage connection must be swapped with the ground-potential. Consequently, the photodiode will be moved from the middle to the periphery, and specially designed light pipes will bring the light to them. At the same time, we will design a high-voltage power supply that will be integrated within the narrow spacing between the two photosensors. Additionally, this assembly must operate at -70 oC. Therefore, we will produce modified photosensors, design and produce all the additional components and interfaces, test the detectors under near-realistic conditions, and share them with our customer/partner for further evaluation and feedback.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR project should help us with providing a new single-photon sensitive detector, named Tandem-ABALONE Module, designed for the IceCube cosmic neutrino experiment at the South Pole - already by far the largest experiment ever built on the planet, but now planning a tenfold extension.

The novel ABALONE Photosensor Technology should enable the IceCube Cosmic Neutrino Experiment (South Pole site)—currently our lead customer/partner—to construct an unprecedentedly large and sensitive next-generation detector, and open a ‘new window to the Universe.’ Furthermore, for the same reason, the leadership of the international APPEC network of next-generation astroparticle physics projects is also counting on our technology for their future projects. IceCube and all of the other large-area experiments in this field, have been so far exclusively based on the expensive, fragile, and performance-limited, 80-year-old Photomultipler Tube manufacture (PMT). An extension on the needed scale calls for profound change in technology, and we have offered a truly singular solution.

During our Phase-1 SBIR Project, we have focused on the key problems associated with the Tandem-ABALONE Module configuration, as well as with the specifics of its implementation at the peculiar South Pole site. In particular, the extremely low temperature and high pressure within the 2450 m deep holes in ice at the IceCube site require profound modifications of the baseline design, which has presented a significant technological challenge. The most disruptive modification to the baseline concept has been in the voltage reversal – Tandem-ABALONE Detector Modules should be electrically grounded on the outside, which poses a particularly challenging multi-faceted technical hurdle. Moreover, all elements comprising a Tandem unit as well as all of their connections should be thermally stable down to about -500 C (Antarctic ice). While not without challenges—that we have largely overcome—the main R&D objectives for the Phase-1 Project have been successfully completed.

Specifically,

  • We produced and tested three fully functional ABALONE units, including low-temperature (-56 C) testing.
  • We designed, purchased parts, and tested the first prototype of the Tandem High Voltage Power Supply Disk.
  • The first pair of light guides have been received from a US manufacturer, and the first 3-D-printing of the composite high-voltage insulator/conductor interface between each of the ABALONE units and the HV power supply Disc has been completed.
  • Our product and the test results were very well received by the IceCube Collaboration on May 8, 2018, at the recent IceCube Collaboration meeting in Atlanta. The presentation was given by Professor Sebastian Boeser (Johannes Guttenberg University, Mainz), the person officially in charge of technology for the IceCube extension project.
  • The IceCube Collaboration has recently received NSF funding for a small-scale upgrade for a specific scientific goal, but now (contrary to some previous agreements), this project includes also a sub-project for R&D and testing of new technologies. This means that we will be able to test Tandem-ABALONE Modules produced within the anticipated Phase-2 SBIR Project (in about 1-3 years from now) in the real environment, and demonstrate the advantages of our technology in a parallel operation with the old PMTs.
  • We have received requests to provide (sell) more evaluation prototypes from several key IceCube members, as well as from researchers working in other experiments (dark matter research, gamma-ray astronomy). At this point, we are not able to produce the needed quantity because our capacity is still too limited, but a Phase-2 Project should allow us to make a major upgrade and distribute dozens of prototypes to all our potential customers.

This SBIR grant has already enabled us to start with the commercialization process, specifically aiming for the IceCube cosmic neutrino experiment, currently our primary customer/partner. The number of modules needed for a full-blown expansion (to take place in 5-10 yeas) should be ~200,000. The production of such a large number of units is feasible by-design, because our technology is manifestly scalable, but it will require significant investment into a large-scale production line. We expect to fully optimize our technology and secure customers for such a large expansion with the help of Phase-2 SBIR Project.

If successful after the completion of both of its phases, this SBIR Project will eventually result in great impacts on the understanding of the universe, education of young scientists, and scientific prestige. In addition, IceCube and its funding agencies, primarily NSF, would be able to claim a new technology spin-off from a manifestly fundamental-science project, which would also address a wide range of societal needs, such as advancements in medical imaging and nuclear security. PhotonLab's technology has four main application areas, each requiring very different R&D and implementation methods: large experiments for fundamental physics research, novel functional medical imaging devices, novel detectors for nuclear security, and oil well logging. The production of thin and lightweight modules of high-performance ABALONE photosensor arrays (comprising much smaller sensors than IceCube) would translate into ultrasensitive PET technology for harmless cancer
